<@U0D9YTXU2|vijayvavdiya> has joined the channel
hey guys, im running into a really bizarre issue currently, hopefully someone can help out
I’m storing some files in Context.getFilesDir()
but when my app is upgraded through the play store or HockeyApp
all of these files just get blown away
is this an inappropriate place to be storing files?
i would say its unexpected that they are being removed as the installs should be a pure upgrade
but depending on which install method you use could definitely do that as an uninstall then install would obviously nuke the files
doesn't seem like the play store should have a problem with that :disappointed:
not sure how hockeyapp works but if it's not a pure "upgrade" that could be the case
I can say with certainty that getFilesDir does not get wiped when upgrading APK via adb
so the packagemanager is not bugged out on marshmallow
<@U0A0S0WG0>: how did you conclude the directory is getting wiped?
Logging statements
It can’t find any of the files after upgrade
wondering if this may be an instance where calling a content provider before launching the application gets you into a bad place
oh wait how are you referencing the files?
is it *always* by `new File(getFilesDir(), name)`
or did you make the mistake of saving their absolute paths?
absolute paths
shit
that’s the problem
thanks
I was starting to lose my mind
<http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Context.html#getFilesDir()>
```The returned path may change over time if the calling app is moved to an adopted storage device, so only relative paths should be persisted.```
so just abandon the .getAbsolutePath() and just call getFilesDir?
correct
honestly getAbsolutePath should be a lint check in core java not just android. The times you ‘should’ be using it are so minimal its effectively never.
I didn’t even realize it could be an issue
the TLDR of your issue though is that your data is probably moving to some user id path’d folder each update so it fails on a simple path change
sounds about right
like /data/23/com.blah.blah/data/…..
yeah, got it
thanks man
saved me from pulling what little hair i had left out
your last name is already White so it wouldn’t be a terrible look
you must get brba references more often than i get omen references lol
haha
you’d be surprised at how many stupid powder references get thrown my way
anyone have a good article or tut on how to use `WebChromeClient.onShowFileChooser`?
<https://github.com/GoogleChrome/chromium-webview-samples/blob/master/input-file-example/app/src/main/java/inputfilesample/android/chrome/google/com/inputfilesample/MainFragment.java#L75>

text: If thats not clear, really its just ‘open’. You can use any file chooser implementation you want to, it just depends on you to give it a URI path back
yeah, sorry, should have stated that i’ve already perused that
it crashes on the Galaxy S5 about 50% of the time
i would recommend you just pass off to the SAF
saf?
storage access framework
it deals with URI’s and gives you access to the system as well as a lot of cloud options
<http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/providers/document-provider.html>

attachments.text: Android 4.4 (API level 19) introduces the Storage Access Framework (SAF). The SAF makes it simple for users to browse and open documents, images, and other files across all of their their preferred document storage providers. A standard, easy-to-use UI…
attachments.fallback: Android 4.4 (API level 19) introduces the Storage Access Framework (SAF). The SAF makes it simple for users to browse and open documents, images, and other files across all of their their preferred document storage providers. A standard, easy-to-use UI…

text: oh okay
nothing to fancy, just using some fancy intent filters to get access to files
am i reading that right?
yep… only works on 4.4.4 ^ though
and you could change the type to **/** for all the things
lol damnit slack..
yeah, im technically supporting 4.3 and up
shit
for 4.3 and lower you either need to write your own file chooser or only let the user open the chooser when file choosing apps are available
man i effing hate `WebView`
if no resolvers are available then the user has no apps that handle the ACTION_PICK intent action
but yes, webview sucks
or you could just do `minSdkVersion=“19”`
I find that works wonders
internally we had to write out own SAF implementation that was backwards compatible for a few specific use cases
backward compatible was a secondary goal with better control being primary
its unfortunately not a realistic option for most people though as you cant access the secure providers

you won’t get paid then, but you’ll be able to forget the older versions at least

file.name: what___s_the_best_way_to_get_a_context_in_a_helper_class_.java
file.title: what’s the best way to get a context in a helper class?
file.preview_highlight:
public static String getQuantityString(int id , int quantity, Object... params){
        Context context= ApplicationContext.getInstance().getContext();
        return context.getResources().getQuantityString(id, quantity, params);
    }

initial_comment.comment: I have a global ApplicationContext, but would it be better to pass it into the function instead? Seems like a waste of time since I only need resources

well by community metrics of github it is the most popular nosql style storage I know of
and do you still have to inherit from Realm’s super type?
yes to *extending* their objects but you *can* have custom methods in your models now
I would still recommend against it though as it keeps you logic cleaner imo
Well just the requirement of extending objects rules out Realm along with most other “ORMs"
for me, anyway
I’d rather write my models in something like ProtoBuf and just generate the persistence layer from that
right
I dont know about passing between threads, I would say not as I believe they are using a lot of ThreadLocal to maintain states
but I haven’t had any issues with threading in realm but I haven’t hit it very hard on that front yet either, at most three threads with only one producing which is pretty light imo
I only used it briefly in the beginning of the year
and our project desperately needed them to add encryption support, but the entire Realm team was still on holiday from Christmas

the end

well, that was the point I was making
but it was medical data so it *had* to be encrypted

gives you an absolute without needing to make an account or something silly just so you can reasonably trust security

attachments.title: When Telcos Customize Crypto
attachments.text: Some of the more interesting Android fragmentation issues (to us anyway) have nothing to do with screen sizes or CPU speeds — instead, we usually find them rooted in something as arcane as telco- or hardware-specific implementations of what you could reasonably assume are “standard” parts of the stack. As your Android app (or in our case, our library) gets deployed to hundreds of millions of devices you’ll see more & more things start breaking. Things that you never expected could even break in the first place… Here’s a particularly “fun” one we encountered recently.
